input:
Does the word "mixture" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
He drank a mixture of beer and lemonade.
The mixture of sulphuric acid and water produces heat.

Does the word "wish" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
He got his wish.
My best wishes.

Does the word "license" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The intolerable license with which the newspapers break ... the rules of decorum -- Edmund Burke.
When liberty becomes license dictatorship is near -- Will Durant.

Does the word "engrave" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Engrave a letter.
Engrave a pen.

Does the word "return" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Return her love.
Return a compliment.

Does the word "brother" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
I would like to thank the brother who just spoke.
None of his brothers would betray him.

Does the word "drought" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
When England defeated Pakistan it ended a ten-year drought.
Farmers most affected by the drought hope that there may yet be sufficient rain early in the growing season.

Does the word "glimpse" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
From the window he could catch a glimpse of the lake.
He caught only a glimpse of the professor's meaning.

Does the word "experience" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A surprising experience.
Experience is the best teacher.

Does the word "horse" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A clothes horse.
500 horse led the attack.

Does the word "fuss" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Don't fuss too much over the grandchildren -- they are quite big now.
She fusses over her husband.

Does the word "education" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A girl's education was less important than a boy's.
Education is a preparation for life.

Does the word "compress" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The force required to compress a spring varies linearly with the displacement.
She compressed her lips.

Does the word "affiliation" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A valuable financial affiliation.
Welcomed the affiliation of the research center with the university.

Does the word "safety" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
He ran to safety.
The reciprocal of safety is risk.

Does the word "pity" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
It's a pity he couldn't do it.
The blind are too often objects of pity.

Does the word "embodiment" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The embodiment of hope.
A circle was the embodiment of his concept of life.

Does the word "rise" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Rise to the occasion.
Her spirits rose when she heard the good news.

Does the word "tremor" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
She felt a tremor in her stomach before going on stage.
Did you feel the tremor this morning?

Does the word "office" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
An executive or judical office.
During his first year in office.

Does the word "upset" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Truman upset Dewey in the 1948 US presidential election.
The foreign team upset the local team.

Does the word "success" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
His success in the marathon was unexpected.
The election was a remarkable success for the Whigs.

Does the word "growth" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A growth of hair.
The growth of culture.

Does the word "construction" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The engineer marvelled at his construction.
Construction is underway on the new bridge.

Does the word "pencil" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
An eyebrow pencil.
This artist's favorite medium is pencil.

Does the word "step" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Always a step behind.
Keep in step with the fashions.

Does the word "delay" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Instant replay caused too long a delay.
The delay before the echo of a sound.

Does the word "motivation" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
We did not understand his motivation.
His motivation was at a high level.

Does the word "branch" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A branch of Congress.
We have branches in all major suburbs.

Does the word "writing" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Writing was a form of therapy for him.
The idea occurs with increasing frequency in Hemingway's writings.

Does the word "distribute" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The publisher wants to distribute the book in Asia.
The function distributes the values evenly.

Does the word "average" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
If you average 10, 20 and 24, you get 18.
The number of hours I work per work averages out to 40.

Does the word "belabor" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Belabor the obvious.
She was belabored by her fellow students.

Does the word "trip" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
A pedestrian was able to trip the burglar as he was running away.
The questions on the test tripped him up.

Does the word "border" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The rug had a wide blue border.
The borders of the garden.

Does the word "impregnation" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The impregnation of wood with preservative.
The impregnation, whatever it was, had turned the rock blue.

Does the word "square" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The carpenter who built this room must have lost his square.
64 is the square of 8.

Does the word "agency" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The superintendence and agency of Providence in the natural world. -- Woodward.
The Central Intelligence Agency.

Does the word "department" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
His work established a new department of literature.
Baking is not my department.

Does the word "crop" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The annual crop of students brings many new ideas.
The latest crop of fashions is about to hit the stores.

Does the word "mess" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The house was a mess.
My boss dumped a whole mess of projects on my desk today.

Does the word "shadiness" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
There's too much shadiness to take good photographs.
The shadiness of their transactions.

Does the word "blockage" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
There was a blockage in the sewer, so we called out the plumber.
We had to call a plumber to clear out the blockage in the drainpipe.

Does the word "catch" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The catch was only 10 fish.
He shared his catch with the others.

Does the word "spread" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The invaders spread their language all over the country.
A big oil spot spread across the water.

Does the word "whitewash" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Let's not whitewash the crimes of Stalin.
In his sermon, the minister didn't try to whitewash over the sins of his church.

Does the word "bite" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Gunny invariably tried to bite her.
As soon as you bite that sandwich, you'll know how good it is.

Does the word "street" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Be careful crossing the street.
The whole street protested the absence of lights.

Does the word "facility" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The assembly plant is an enormous facility.
Educational facilities.

Does the word "loose" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Let loose mines.
Loose terrible plagues upon humanity.

Does the word "go" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
How did your interview go?
She was going that way anyway, so she offered to show him where it was.

Does the word "recreation" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
For recreation he wrote poetry and solved crossword puzzles.
Drug abuse is often regarded as a form of recreation.

Does the word "nut" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
He was driving his car like a nut.
I kicked him in the nuts.

Does the word "afflict" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Afflict with the plague.
She was afflicted by the death of her parents.

Does the word "plenty" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
There was plenty of food for everyone.
It must have cost plenty.

Does the word "protest" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
The senator rose to register his protest.
They finished the game under protest to the league president.

Does the word "intellect" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
He has a keen intellect.
Some of the world's leading intellects were meeting there.

Does the word "replicate" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
On entering a host cell, a virus will start to replicate.
Replicate the cell.

Does the word "recruit" have the same meaning in these two sentences?
Recruit new soldiers.
The lab director recruited an able crew of assistants.
